name: Yaki Udon (Japanese Stir-Fried Udon Noodles)
description: Yaki Udon is Japanese stir-fried udon noodles made with your choice of protein and vegetables seasoned with a savory sauce. This recipe is easily vegetarian or vegan adaptable. It‚Äòs ready in 25 minutes and incredibly delicious!

video.description:
Yaki Udon is Japanese stir-fried udon noodles made with your choice of protein and vegetables seasoned with a savory sauce. This recipe is easily vegetarian or vegan adaptable. It‚Äôs ready in 25 minutes and incredibly delicious!

PRINT RECIPE ‚ñ∂ https://www.justonecookbook.com/yaki-udon/

INGREDIENTS

¬Ω onion (3.5 oz, 100 g for 2 servings)
2-3 leaves cabbage (8 oz, 227 g for 2 servings)
2 inches carrot (1.8 oz, 50 g for 2 servings)
2 shiitake mushrooms (0.7 oz, 20 g for 2 servings)
2 green onions/scallions
6 oz sliced pork belly (use your choice of meat or seafood; omit for vegetarian/vegan and use tofu, mushrooms, or extra vegetables instead)
2 servings udon noodles (6.3 oz/180 g dry udon noodles; 1.1 lb/500 g frozen or parboiled udon noodles)
1 Tbsp neutral-flavored oil (vegetable, rice bran, canola, etc.) (for cooking)
‚Öõ tsp kosher salt (Diamond Crystal; use half for table salt) (plus more to taste)
‚Öõ tsp freshly ground black pepper (plus more to taste)

For the Seasonings Option A
¬Ω tsp dashi powder (use kombu dashi powder for vegetarian/vegan or skip)
2 Tbsp soy sauce
1 Tbsp sake
1 tsp mirin (or a pinch of sugar)

For the Seasonings Option B
3 Tbsp mentsuyu/tsuyu (concentrated noodle soup base) (the mentsuyu I use is 3-times concentrated; if you use non-concentrated mentsuyu, please add more to achieve the same flavor; here's my Homemade Mentsuyu recipe)
1 tsp soy sauce
For the Garnish (Optional)
3 Tbsp katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes) (or 1-2 small packages of katsuobushi; skip for vegetarian/vegan)
2 Tbsp pickled red ginger (beni shoga or kizami beni shoga)

INSTRUCTIONS with step-by-step pics ‚ñ∂ https://www.justonecookbook.com/yaki-udon/

How to Make Yaki Udon (Japanese Stir-Fried Udon Noodles) (Recipe) ÁÑº„Åç„ÅÜ„Å©„Çì„ÅÆ‰Ωú„ÇäÊñπ („É¨„Ç∑„Éî)

recipeYield: 2 (could be 3, depending on the extra ingredients you add)
recipeIngredient: ‚Öõ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt ((plus more to taste))
‚Öõ tsp freshly ground black pepper ((plus more to taste))
¬Ω tsp dashi powder ((use kombu dashi powder for vegetarian/vegan or skip))
1 tsp mirin ((or a pinch of sugar))
3 Tbsp katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes) ((or 1‚Äì2 small packages of katsuobushi; skip for vegetarian/vegan))
2 Tbsp pickled red ginger (beni shoga or kizami beni shoga)

recipeInstructions.text: Gather all the ingredients. For this recipe demonstration, I used seasonings option A. Start bringing a large pot of water to a boil on medium-high heat for heating or cooking the udon noodles later.
recipeInstructions.name: Gather all the ingredients. For this recipe demonstration, I used seasonings option A. Start bringing a large pot of water to a boil on medium-high heat for heating or cooking the udon noodles later.

itemListElement.text: Remove the tough core of 2‚Äì3 leaves green cabbage. Then, cut the leaves into pieces about 1 inch (2.5 cm) square.
itemListElement.name: Remove the tough core of 2‚Äì3 leaves green cabbage. Then, cut the leaves into pieces about 1 inch (2.5 cm) square.

itemListElement.text: Peel 2 inches carrot and cut it into thin slabs. Then, julienne them into strips 2 inches (5 cm) long.
itemListElement.name: Peel 2 inches carrot and cut it into thin slabs. Then, julienne them into strips 2 inches (5 cm) long.

itemListElement.text: Discard the tough stems of 2 shiitake mushrooms and slice the mushroom caps.
itemListElement.name: Discard the tough stems of 2 shiitake mushrooms and slice the mushroom caps.

itemListElement.text: Cut 2 green onions/scallions into 2-inch (5 cm) pieces. Cut 6 oz sliced pork belly slices into 1-inch (2.5 cm) pieces.
itemListElement.name: Cut 2 green onions/scallions into 2-inch (5 cm) pieces. Cut 6 oz sliced pork belly slices into 1-inch (2.5 cm) pieces.

itemListElement.text: When the water is boiling, blanch 2 servings udon noodles (frozen) for 30‚Äì40 seconds or until it just starts to loosen up. If you‚Äòre using dry udon noodles, boil them according to the package instructions. Transfer the noodles to a plate and set aside.
itemListElement.name: When the water is boiling, blanch 2 servings udon noodles (frozen) for 30‚Äì40 seconds or until it just starts to loosen up. If you‚Äòre using dry udon noodles, boil them according to the package instructions. Transfer the noodles to a plate and set aside.

itemListElement.text: Preheat a large frying pan over medium heat. When the pan is hot, add 1 Tbsp neutral oil and spread it evenly. Add the pork belly and stir-fry.
itemListElement.name: Preheat a large frying pan over medium heat. When the pan is hot, add 1 Tbsp neutral oil and spread it evenly. Add the pork belly and stir-fry.

itemListElement.text: Season the pork with ‚Öõ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt and ‚Öõ tsp freshly ground black pepper. Cook until it‚Äòs no longer pink.
itemListElement.name: Season the pork with ‚Öõ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt and ‚Öõ tsp freshly ground black pepper. Cook until it‚Äòs no longer pink.

itemListElement.text: Add the onion slices and stir-fry until tender.
itemListElement.name: Add the onion slices and stir-fry until tender.

itemListElement.text: Add the cabbage, carrot strips, shiitake mushrooms, and green onions. Mix it all together until the ingredients are coated with oil.
itemListElement.name: Add the cabbage, carrot strips, shiitake mushrooms, and green onions. Mix it all together until the ingredients are coated with oil.

itemListElement.text: Cover with a lid and reduce the stove‚Äòs heat to low. Let the ingredients steam for 3 minutes, or until the ingredients are slightly wilted.
itemListElement.name: Cover with a lid and reduce the stove‚Äòs heat to low. Let the ingredients steam for 3 minutes, or until the ingredients are slightly wilted.

itemListElement.text: Add the udon noodles to the pan and toss with a pair of tongs to combine (it‚Äòs a lot easier to use tongs than two spatulas).
itemListElement.name: Add the udon noodles to the pan and toss with a pair of tongs to combine (it‚Äòs a lot easier to use tongs than two spatulas).

itemListElement.text: Add the ingredients for either seasonings option A or B to the pan. For option A, add ¬Ω tsp dashi powder, 2 Tbsp soy sauce, 1 Tbsp sake, and 1 tsp mirin. If you‚Äòre using option B, add 3 Tbsp mentsuyu (concentrated noodle soup base) and 1 tsp soy sauce. Tip: If you have mentsuyu at home, definitely try my go-to seasonings option B because it‚Äòs easy and delicious!
itemListElement.name: Add the ingredients for either seasonings option A or B to the pan. For option A, add ¬Ω tsp dashi powder, 2 Tbsp soy sauce, 1 Tbsp sake, and 1 tsp mirin. If you‚Äòre using option B, add 3 Tbsp mentsuyu (concentrated noodle soup base) and 1 tsp soy sauce. Tip: If you have mentsuyu at home, definitely try my go-to seasonings option B because it‚Äòs easy and delicious!

itemListElement.text: Mix it all together. Taste and adjust the seasoning, adding more ground black pepper and salt to your liking.
itemListElement.name: Mix it all together. Taste and adjust the seasoning, adding more ground black pepper and salt to your liking.

itemListElement.text: Transfer the Yaki Udon to individual plates. Optionally, sprinkle 3 Tbsp katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes) on top and garnish with 2 Tbsp pickled red ginger (beni shoga or kizami beni shoga) on the side.
itemListElement.name: Transfer the Yaki Udon to individual plates. Optionally, sprinkle 3 Tbsp katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes) on top and garnish with 2 Tbsp pickled red ginger (beni shoga or kizami beni shoga) on the side.

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3‚Äì4 days and in the freezer for a month.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3‚Äì4 days and in the freezer for a month.

review.reviewBody: Love love love this recipe!  One suggestion would be a small note with the Store bites on best method to reheat‚Äîthis would probably be useful for all your recipes.

Delicious and EASY!  When I‚Äôm pressed for time I‚Äôll use precut tri-color slaw for the veg. Any meat I‚Äôve got around works, I‚Äôve usually got something in the fridge that will make this dish come together in minutes.  When using beef I like to marinate it with grated garlic, ginger, soy sauce, and a little bit of baking soda so it‚Äôs super tender.

AMAZING restaurant quality flavor. I skipped the dashi to make it vegan and didn't have the vegan dashi yet. Flavor was still amazing and exactly how I get it in restaurants. I used frozen sanuki udon and added 1/2 block tofu so I added an extra serving of sauce and cooked the tofu first. Only partly cooking the sanuki udon makes the noodles the perfect texture. And it's such a super easy recipe that lets you cook it in 5-10 min

I used frozen udon noodles, mentsuyu and soy, carrots, purple cabbage (I wish I had green, the purple was a bit strong for my liking), carrots, yellow onion, green onion, and entirely too much thin sliced beef (I wanted to use it up before it went bad). This turned out very good considering I've never tried to make any Japanese dish other than sushi. I'm excited to make it again. Thanks so much JOC!
Thank you, Nami for another excellent simple and quick meal! I already had everything on hand and your recipe was loved by my kids and husband!

This one is a keeper! I don't care for cabbage, so I added cut up celery. Used beef as my protein. Will be making this again! I also used a cut up bag of broccoli, cauliflower and carrots. Put in 1/2 cup of water with my 3 TBL of concentrated mentsuyu. Made just little broth, that I am sure will be soaked up by the noodles! If I could give it more than 5 stars I would!
I was thinking about making this with shrimp and remembered Ranch 99 in Daily City. The only place I‚Äôve ever seen live Spot Prawns! Miss living in the Bay Area. üôÅ
